title: UX & Navigation Improvement Plan
text:
Last Updated: January 20, 2026
Prepared By: UX Expert Review




Your Liaison Program website has excellent foundational content but needs significant UX improvements to match research lab standards. Inspired by the SIM Lab website design (sim-lab-siue.github.io), this plan addresses:

Navigation clarity - Streamline multi-level menus
Visual hierarchy - Add research themes and visual appeal
Accessibility - Improve readability and navigation flow
Information architecture - Reorganize content for discovery
Branding - Create a cohesive research lab aesthetic








Clean Quarto/Bootstrap framework
Logical five-phase structure
Good content organization (sidebar + navbar)
Mobile-responsive design
Search functionality
Clear calls-to-action on home page





Navigation overload: Too many items in navbar (7 items + dropdown)
Unclear hierarchy: Sidebar duplicates navbar; confusing for new users
Generic design: Looks like a generic course site, not a research program
Missing context: No research themes/focus areas like SIM Lab
Poor discoverability: Phase content pages are empty/minimal
Mobile experience: Sidebar navigation not optimized for phones
Visual identity: No branding, icons, or visual differentiation
Internal links: Not all modules have content; broken navigation paths
Contact info scattered: About page isolated; no footer with contact info
No visual hierarchy on homepage: Three buttons look the same; canâ€™t scan quickly








âœ… Homepage hero section with lab introduction
âœ… Research theme cards - 3 distinct research areas with descriptions
âœ… Clean navbar - HOME | ABOUT | PROJECTS | (minimal)
âœ… Footer with contact - Email, office hours, social links
âœ… Project pages - Individual research projects with details
âœ… Team/people section - Director bio, lab members
âœ… Visual branding - Consistent colors, imagery, typography
âœ… Mobile-first layout - Content reflows well on small screens









Current Problem: Navbar has â€œPhasesâ€ dropdown + sidebar duplication
Impact: Users donâ€™t know which nav to use; mobile nav breaks
Action Items: - [ ] Remove sidebar navigation on mobile (or make collapsible only) - [ ] Simplify navbar: HOME | SYLLABUS | PHASES | RESOURCES | ABOUT - [ ] Keep â€œPhasesâ€ as a dropdown with 5 items - [ ] Move â€œVault Downloadâ€ to Resources page (not navbar) - [ ] Remove â€œContactâ€ from navbar; add to footer
New Navbar Structure:

â”œâ”€ Setup Guide

SYLLABUS

PHASES (dropdown)

ABOUT

â”œâ”€ Lab info
â”œâ”€ Contact



Current Problem: Sidebar lists every page; creates cognitive overload
Impact: Users scroll forever; key pages hidden
Action Items: - [ ] Create distinct sidebar sections for each phase - [ ] Collapse phases by default on mobile - [ ] Show expanded current phase only - [ ] Add visual indicators (icons) for each phase - [ ] Keep â€œStart Hereâ€ section always visible







Current Problem: Homepage is text-heavy; no visual anchors
Impact: Users donâ€™t immediately understand the program value
Changes: - [ ] Add a hero banner with course title + tagline - [ ] Include an optional hero image (lab photo, abstract design) - [ ] Create a concise 1-2 sentence tagline about the liaison role - [ ] Replace three button CTA with visual grid of four key actions:

Current Problem: Home page jumps to phases without explaining context
Impact: New students donâ€™t understand why this matters
Changes: - [ ] Add section: â€œYour Role as a Communication Liaisonâ€ - [ ] Explain 3 key competencies youâ€™ll develop - [ ] Show typical career paths or applications - [ ] Include a visual timeline/roadmap of 5 phases



Current Problem: All buttons look similar; no priority hierarchy
Impact: Users unsure what to do first
Changes: - [ ] Primary CTA: â€œGet Startedâ€ (bright color, prominent) - [ ] Secondary CTAs: â€œView Syllabusâ€, â€œDownload Vaultâ€, â€œAboutâ€ - [ ] Use badges/labels: â€œQuick (10 min)â€, â€œDownloadâ€, etc.







Current Problem: No visual identity; looks generic
Impact: Doesnâ€™t feel like a professional research program
Changes: - [ ] Create a lab name/identifier in header (e.g., â€œMC Research Methods Labâ€ or â€œThe Liaison Labâ€) - [ ] Add a lab logo or icon (optional but recommended) - [ ] Create a color scheme inspired by your university branding - [ ] Use consistent typography for headings

website:
  title: "MC Research Methods: The Liaison Program"
  navbar:
    logo: "images/lab-logo.png"  # Optional
    background: "#2c5aa0"  # University brand color
    
format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
    css: custom-styling.scss



Current Problem: Text-only navigation is boring
Impact: Harder to scan; less engaging
Changes: - [ ] Add phase icons (ğŸ§­ Orientation, ğŸ” Discovery, ğŸ“– Dictionary, âš™ï¸ Execution, ğŸ¯ Delivery) - [ ] Add icons to navbar items - [ ] Use icons in phase index pages - [ ] Create visual cards for resources instead of plain lists



Current Problem: Dense text blocks; hard to read
Impact: Reduced engagement
Changes: - [ ] Increase line height (1.8 for body text) - [ ] Add more whitespace between sections - [ ] Use color for emphasis (highlights, callout boxes) - [ ] Create visual hierarchy: H1 > H2 > H3 with distinct sizes







Current Problem: Phase pages have different structures; some are empty
Impact: Inconsistent user experience

Current Problem: Most phase index pages are placeholders
Impact: Users canâ€™t tell what comes in each phase
Changes: - [ ] Add 3-5 learning objectives per phase - [ ] Add section descriptions (what will students do?) - [ ] Add time estimates per phase - [ ] Create individual lesson/chapter pages - [ ] Add preview of assignments/deliverables



Current Problem: No â€œNext Phaseâ€ buttons; hard to flow through course
Impact: Students get stuck; have to use sidebar
Changes: - [ ] Add footer nav: â† Phase [N-1] | Phase [N+1] â†’ - [ ] Make footer nav sticky on mobile - [ ] Add progress indicator (e.g., â€œPhase 2 of 5â€)







Current Problem: Resources are mixed (downloads, tools, guides)
Impact: Hard to find what you need
New Structure:
RESOURCES & DOWNLOADS

Current Problem: Plain list format; hard to scan
Impact: Reduced discoverability
Changes: - [ ] Convert links to visual cards with icons - [ ] Add time estimates per resource - [ ] Add difficulty level (Beginner/Intermediate/Advanced) - [ ] Use consistent card styling







Current Problem: Some text may not meet WCAG AA standards
Impact: Hard to read for low-vision users
Changes: - [ ] Run site through WAVE or Axe accessibility checker - [ ] Ensure 4.5:1 contrast ratio for all body text - [ ] Use color + icons (not color alone) for important info



Current Problem: Sidebar doesnâ€™t collapse well on mobile
Impact: Unusable on phones
Changes: - [ ] Hide sidebar on screens <768px - [ ] Use hamburger menu for main nav - [ ] Make navbar items larger for touch targets (48px minimum) - [ ] Test on iPhone, Android, tablet



Current Problem: Screen readers canâ€™t navigate efficiently
Impact: Inaccessible to blind/visually impaired users
Changes: - [ ] Add skip-to-content link at top of page - [ ] Add proper ARIA labels to navbar items - [ ] Use semantic HTML (nav, main, footer, article) - [ ] Add alt text to all images



Current Problem: Some links are unclear (e.g., â€œhereâ€ is a link)
Impact: Screen reader users confused
Changes: - [ ] Make all link text descriptive - [ ] Example: Change â€œPreview it hereâ€ â†’ â€œPreview Weekly Journal Templateâ€ - [ ] Add (external) indicator to external links







Current Problem: No footer; contact info only on About page
Impact: Hard to reach instructor; no site-wide context

Current Problem: Contact info hidden on About page
Impact: New students canâ€™t find how to reach you
Changes: - [ ] Add email link in navbar (right side) - [ ] Add office hours in footer - [ ] Make footer sticky on mobile so contact is always visible








These changes provide immediate UX improvements:

Simplify navbar - Remove duplication with sidebar
Create footer with contact info
Add visual icons to phases and navbar items
Improve homepage - Add phase grid/cards
Fix mobile nav - Collapse sidebar on mobile

Estimated Effort: 4-6 hours
Impact: High - Immediate usability improvement



Improve content and information architecture:

Flesh out phase pages - Add learning objectives, modules
Reorganize Resources page - Create card layout
Add phase navigation - Previous/Next buttons
Create templates for consistent page structure
Add progress indicators - Show user position in course

Estimated Effort: 6-8 hours
Impact: Medium - Better content discovery and flow



Polish visual design and branding:

Create custom CSS for brand colors and typography
Add lab branding - Logo, colors, consistent design
Improve Typography - Better spacing, contrast
Create resource cards - Visual redesign of downloads
Add hero section - Homepage visual appeal

Estimated Effort: 6-8 hours
Impact: Medium-High - Professional appearance



Ensure accessibility and test across devices:

Run accessibility audit - WAVE, Axe tools
Fix color contrast issues
Test mobile - iPhone, Android, tablet
Add ARIA labels for screen readers
Test keyboard navigation - Can tab through all content?

Estimated Effort: 4-6 hours
Impact: High - Legal compliance + inclusive design

about.qmd - Move to footer, create more comprehensive contact

custom-styling.scss - Custom CSS for branding
_includes/footer.html - Custom footer template
images/ folder - Store icons, logo, images
resources/setup-guides/ - Separate guide files for each tool








Based on academic/research lab aesthetic: - Primary: Dark blue (#2c5aa0) - Authority, trustworthiness - Secondary: Teal (#17a2b8) - Innovation, growth - Accent: Orange (#fd7e14) - Engagement, energy - Text: Dark gray (#212529) - Readability - Background: Off-white (#f8f9fa) - Reduced eye strain




Headings: System fonts (font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, â€œSegoe UIâ€)
Body: 18px/1.8 line-height for accessibility
Code: Monospace (maintain readability)





Max content width: 900px (readable line length)
Sidebar width: 280px (scannability)
Mobile breakpoint: 768px
Spacing: 1.5rem base unit (consistent rhythm)









Home â†’ Setup â†’ Resources
Navbar â€œPhasesâ€ dropdown â†’ All 5 phase pages
Sidebar â†’ All major sections
Resources page â†’ Download links
Footer (none) - MISSING





Sidebar â€œOrientationâ€ â†’ Chapter 01 link exists but page may be empty
Phase pages â†’ No forward/back navigation
Footer â†’ No footer exists
Contact â†’ Only on About page (not in navbar)





Add footer navigation with key links
Add Previous/Next phase buttons on each phase page
Test all internal links for validity
Create breadcrumb navigation on nested pages







Bounce rate - Are new users staying longer?
Average session duration - Deeper engagement?
Page depth - Are users exploring more pages?
Mobile traffic % - Is mobile usability improving?
Accessibility score - Run Lighthouse audit
Search functionality usage - Are students using search?

Collapse sidebar on mobile (1 hour)

Use Quartoâ€™s responsive sidebar config

Add â€œPrevious/Next Phaseâ€ nav (1 hour)

Add at bottom of each phase page

Improve homepage with grid layout (1-2 hours)

Replace three buttons with 2Ã—2 grid

Review this plan - Do the recommendations align with your vision?
Prioritize changes - Which items matter most to your students?
Set timeline - When can you dedicate time to implement?
Start with Phase 1 - Quick wins for immediate impact
Test with users - Get student feedback on changes


Need help implementing? This plan is detailed enough to hand to a developer or work through yourself. Each section has specific, actionable items with time estimates.

title: Setting Up VS Code
text:
VS Code is a professional code editor that makes working with data science, web development, and automation projects more efficient. This guide covers installation and recommended setup for the course.


Visual Studio Code (VS Code) is a lightweight but powerful code editor that supports: - Multiple programming languages (Python, JavaScript, R, and more) - Git/GitHub integration for version control - Extensions for enhanced functionality - Integrated terminal for running commands








Go to VS Code Download
Click â€œDownload for Windowsâ€
Run the installer (.exe file)
Follow the setup wizard:

Accept the license agreement
Choose installation location (default is fine)
Important: Check â€œAdd to PATHâ€ (allows opening folders from terminal)
Check â€œRegister Code as an editorâ€¦â€ (optional but useful)

Click Install and wait for completion (2-3 minutes)





Search for â€œVisual Studio Codeâ€ in Windows Start menu
Or open a terminal and type: code









Go to VS Code Download
Click â€œDownload for Macâ€

Choose Intel if you have an older Mac
Choose Apple Silicon if you have an M1/M2/M3 chip

Open the downloaded .zip file
Drag Visual Studio Code to the Applications folder
Installation is instant!





Find in Applications folder, or
Use Spotlight search: Press Cmd+Space, type â€œVisual Studio Codeâ€
Or from terminal: code (see setup note below)

Terminal Setup (Optional but Recommended)
To use code command from terminal: 1. Open VS Code 2. Press Cmd+Shift+P to open Command Palette 3. Type: code 4. Select â€œShell Command: Install â€˜codeâ€™ command in PATHâ€







Option A: Using apt (recommended)
sudo apt update
sudo apt install software-properties-common apt-transport-https wget
wget -q https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc -O- | sudo apt-key add -
sudo add-apt-repository "deb [arch=amd64] https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/vscode stable main"
sudo apt update
sudo apt install code
Option B: Direct download 1. Go to VS Code Download 2. Download the .deb file for Linux 3. Install: sudo dpkg -i code_*.deb



code






Extensions add functionality to VS Code. Install these for maximum productivity:



Open VS Code
Click the Extensions icon (square icon on left sidebar)
Search for each extension below and click Install












Extension
Publisher
Purpose




Python
Microsoft
Python language support, debugging, linting


Pylance
Microsoft
Advanced Python type checking and IntelliSense


GitHub Copilot
GitHub
AI-powered code suggestions (requires GitHub account)


GitLens
GitKraken
Enhanced Git integration and history


Git Graph
mhutchie
Visual Git branch viewer


Markdown All in One
Yu Zhang
Better Markdown support


Quarto
Quarto
Quarto document support


Thunder Client

title: Setting Up VS Code
text: Visual Studio Code (VS Code) is a lightweight but powerful code editor that supports: - Multiple programming languages (Python, JavaScript, R, and more) - Git/GitHub integration for version control - Extensions for enhanced functionality - Integrated terminal for running commands

title: Setting Up VS Code
text:
Go to VS Code Download
Click â€œDownload for Windowsâ€
Run the installer (.exe file)
Follow the setup wizard:

Accept the license agreement
Choose installation location (default is fine)
Important: Check â€œAdd to PATHâ€ (allows opening folders from terminal)
Check â€œRegister Code as an editorâ€¦â€ (optional but useful)

Click Install and wait for completion (2-3 minutes)





Search for â€œVisual Studio Codeâ€ in Windows Start menu
Or open a terminal and type: code









Go to VS Code Download
Click â€œDownload for Macâ€

Choose Intel if you have an older Mac
Choose Apple Silicon if you have an M1/M2/M3 chip

Open the downloaded .zip file
Drag Visual Studio Code to the Applications folder
Installation is instant!





Find in Applications folder, or
Use Spotlight search: Press Cmd+Space, type â€œVisual Studio Codeâ€
Or from terminal: code (see setup note below)

Terminal Setup (Optional but Recommended)
To use code command from terminal: 1. Open VS Code 2. Press Cmd+Shift+P to open Command Palette 3. Type: code 4. Select â€œShell Command: Install â€˜codeâ€™ command in PATHâ€







Option A: Using apt (recommended)
sudo apt update
sudo apt install software-properties-common apt-transport-https wget
wget -q https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc -O- | sudo apt-key add -
sudo add-apt-repository "deb [arch=amd64] https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/vscode stable main"
sudo apt update
sudo apt install code
Option B: Direct download 1. Go to VS Code Download 2. Download the .deb file for Linux 3. Install: sudo dpkg -i code_*.deb

title: ğŸ“š Resources & Downloads
text:
FAQ
Q: Do I need to download the textbook?
A: No, itâ€™s optional. You can access course readings through the library or online sources.
Q: Can I use Excel instead of R?
A: Yes, Excel works for basic analysis. R is recommended for more complex projects.
Q: What if I already use a note-taking app?
A: Obsidian is recommended but optional. The course works with Notion, OneNote, or even physical notebooks.
Q: Where do I turn in my work?
A: Save deliverables in your Liaison_Vault under 03_Project/. Dr.Â Leith will collect via email or learning management system.
Q: Can I work with others?
A: Absolutely! Pair programming and collaborative analysis are encouraged. Document who contributed what.
Q: What if I fall behind?
A: Reach out to Dr.Â Leith early. The phases are structured but flexibleâ€”we can adjust timelines if needed.
Q: Are there textbooks or readings?
A: Course readings will be posted in each phase. Check Phase 1 for the syllabus.

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text: Obsidian is a powerful note-taking and knowledge management app that stores all your files as plain markdown. You own your dataâ€”everything is stored locally on your computer, and you can sync it however you want (or not at all). This guide covers the basics and how to customize your workspace with plugins and themes.

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text: Obsidian is a powerful note-taking and knowledge management app that stores all your files as plain markdown. You own your dataâ€”everything is stored locally on your computer, and you can sync it however you want (or not at all). This guide covers the basics and how to customize your workspace with plugins and themes.

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Step 1: Install Obsidian

Go to obsidian.md
Click Download and choose your operating system (Windows, Mac, or Linux)
Run the installer and follow the prompts
Open Obsidian when installation is complete

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Step 2: Open Your First Vault
A vault is a folder that Obsidian manages. The Liaison Program provides a pre-configured vault.

2.1 Extract the Liaison Vault

Download Liaison_Vault.zip from the Resources page
Extract it to a location like:

Windows: C:\Users\YourName\Documents\Liaison_Vault
Mac: ~/Documents/Liaison_Vault
Linux: ~/Documents/Liaison_Vault




2.2 Open the Vault in Obsidian

Open Obsidian
Click Open folder as vault
Navigate to where you extracted Liaison_Vault and select it
Click Open

Obsidian will now show your vault with all the pre-configured folders and templates!

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Step 3: Navigate Your Vault

The Sidebar
On the left side of Obsidian, youâ€™ll see:

File Explorer: Shows all folders and files in your vault
Search: Find notes by keyword
Starred: Quick access to your favorite notes
Backlinks: See how notes are connected



The Ribbon (Left Edge)
The leftmost thin bar has icons for: - Create new note - Open vault settings - View help


The Main Editor
Click any note to open it and start writing. Notes are stored as .md (markdown) files.

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Step 4: Community Plugins
Obsidian has a large community that creates plugins to extend functionality. Hereâ€™s how to install them.

4.1 Enable Community Plugins
By default, community plugins are disabled. To enable them:

Click the Settings icon (gear icon) in the bottom left
Go to Community plugins
Click Turn on community plugins (if itâ€™s greyed out, theyâ€™re already on)



4.2 Install a Plugin: QMD as Markdown
The textbook chapters are in .qmd format (Quarto markdown). Obsidian doesnâ€™t recognize this format by default, but the qmd as md plugin fixes this.
To install it:

In Settings, go to Community plugins
Click Browse (or search icon)
Search for â€œqmd as mdâ€ (by Daniel Borek)
Click the result to open the plugin page
Click Install
Once installed, click Enable to turn it on

Now you can view and edit .qmd files just like regular markdown files!


4.3 Other Useful Plugins
Here are some community plugins that work great with the Liaison Program:







Plugin
What It Does




Dataview
Query and display your notes as databases/lists


Calendar
Visual calendar for journal entries


Templater
Advanced template features beyond Obsidianâ€™s built-in system


Daily Notes
Automatically create and link daily notes


Task
Advanced task management with due dates and status


Excalidraw
Draw diagrams and sketches within notes



To install any of these, repeat steps 2-5 above with the plugin name.

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Step 5: Customize with Themes
Obsidian comes with a light and dark theme by default, but the community has created hundreds more. Hereâ€™s how to change themes.

5.1 Access Themes

Open Settings (gear icon, bottom left)
Go to Appearance
Scroll to Themes section



5.2 Choose a Built-in Theme
Under â€œManageâ€, youâ€™ll see two built-in themes: - Default Light Theme - Default Dark Theme (recommended for long study sessions)
Click either to apply it immediately.


5.3 Install Community Themes
For custom themes from the community:

Make sure community plugins are enabled (see Step 4.1)
In Appearance, look for Manage button next to Themes
Click Manage (or the folder icon)
Click Browse in the top right
Search for a theme name (e.g., â€œMinimalâ€, â€œNordâ€, â€œDraculaâ€)
Click the theme to see a preview
Click Install and then Use



5.4 Popular Themes
Some community favorites:

Minimal - Clean, distraction-free interface
Nord - Cool blue color scheme, easy on the eyes
Dracula - Dark theme with vibrant accent colors
Cybertron - Modern, sleek design
Things - Inspired by the Things app, very polished

Try a few and find what works best for you!

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Step 6: Essential Settings

6.1 File Management
In Settings â†’ Files & Links: - Default location for new notes: Choose where new notes appear (e.g., â€œInboxâ€ folder) - Show unsaved indicator: Helpful to know when to save


6.2 Editor Settings
In Settings â†’ Editor: - Strict line breaks: Makes formatting more predictable - Line numbers: Toggle on/off based on preference - Indent size: Set to 2 or 4 spaces (2 is cleaner for markdown)


6.3 Hotkeys
In Settings â†’ Hotkeys, you can set keyboard shortcuts for common actions: - Toggle sidebar (great for focus mode) - Create new note - Search in vault - Follow backlinks


6.4 Sync & Backup
In Settings â†’ About, youâ€™ll see sync options: - Obsidian Sync (paid): Cloud sync across devices - Git: Use Git to version control your vault (recommended for this course!) - Manual backups: Copy your vault folder regularly
For the Liaison Program, using Git is recommended so you can version control your work.

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Step 7: Basic Markdown Syntax
Notes in Obsidian use markdown. Here are the essentials:



Syntax
Result




# Heading 1
Large heading


## Heading 2
Medium heading


### Heading 3
Small heading


**Bold text**
Bold text


*Italic text*
Italic text


- List item
Bullet list


1. Numbered item
Numbered list


[Link text](https://example.com)
Hyperlink


[[Note name]]
Link to another note in your vault


> Quote
Block quote


`code`
Inline code

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Step 8: Create Your First Note
Letâ€™s practice:

Click the â€œCreate new noteâ€ icon (top left, looks like a page)
Type a title like â€œMy First Noteâ€
Start writing in markdown:

# My First Note

## What I'm Learning

- Obsidian basics
- Markdown syntax
- How to organize my research

## Goals

1. Complete the Liaison Program
2. Master data analysis
3. Tell stories with data

Obsidian saves automaticallyâ€”no need to click Save!
Notice the file appears in your vault in the File Explorer (left sidebar)

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Step 9: Connect Your Notes (Backlinks)
One powerful feature of Obsidian is linking notes together. This creates a â€œknowledge graphâ€ of your research.

9.1 Create a Link
In any note, type [[ and start typing a note name:
# My Research

I'm reading [[Weekly Journal Template]] to understand the reflection process.

I also reference [[02_Literature]] for my sources.
Obsidian will suggest existing notes. Select one or type a new name to create a new linked note.


9.2 View Backlinks
On the right side of any note, youâ€™ll see a Backlinks panel. This shows all notes that link to the current noteâ€”a powerful way to see connections in your research!

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Step 10: Tips for Success

Keep It Simple
Donâ€™t over-customize at first. Start with the default theme and no plugins. Add what you need as you go.


Use the Vault Structure
The Liaison_Vault comes pre-organized: - 00_Inbox: Capture ideas quickly here - 01_Journal: Weekly reflections - 02_Literature: Research notes and citations - 03_Project: Your active research work - 04_Resources: Attach images, PDFs, videos
Follow this structure to stay organized.


Back Up Your Work
If using Git:
git add .
git commit -m "Update research notes"
git push
Or regularly copy your Liaison_Vault folder to an external drive.


Embrace Plain Text
One beauty of Obsidian is that everything is plain markdown. You can: - Open notes in any text editor - Version control with Git - Search with command-line tools - Never worry about proprietary formats

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Troubleshooting

QMD Files Wonâ€™t Open
Make sure youâ€™ve installed and enabled the qmd as md plugin (see Step 4.2).


Plugin Not Showing
Try restarting Obsidian. Sometimes plugins need to reload.


Canâ€™t Find My Vault
Make sure you opened the correct folder as a vault. Look for a .obsidian folder inside your vault folderâ€”thatâ€™s how Obsidian knows itâ€™s a vault.


Performance Slow
If Obsidian feels sluggish: - Disable unused plugins - Check your note count (very large vaults may slow down) - Restart Obsidian

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Next Steps

âœ… Install Obsidian
âœ… Extract and open the Liaison_Vault
âœ… Install the qmd as md plugin
âœ… Choose a theme you like
âœ… Create your first note
âœ… Explore the vault structure
Start the Liaison Program!

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Resources

Obsidian Help: help.obsidian.md
Markdown Guide: markdownguide.org
Obsidian Community: obsidian.md/community
Plugin Directory: obsidian.md/plugins

title: Getting Started with Obsidian
text:
Questions?
If you get stuck: 1. Check the Obsidian Help documentation 2. Search the community forum 3. Check your vaultâ€™s .obsidian folder settings 4. Come to office hours!

title: âš™ï¸ Phase 4: Execution
text:
Duration: Weeks 8-10 | Time Commitment: ~10 hours
Collect, clean, and analyze your data

title: âš™ï¸ Phase 4: Execution
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of Phase 4, you will:


âœ… Collect data according to your research plan
âœ… Clean and verify data quality
âœ… Document all data transformation steps
âœ… Perform preliminary analysis
âœ… Generate visualizations and summary tables
âœ… Communicate findings and limitations

title: âš™ï¸ Phase 4: Execution
text:
What Youâ€™ll Do
Phase 4 is where you execute your plan:
Collect - Gather data using your approved methods (surveys, interviews, scraping, etc.)
Clean - Verify quality, handle missing values, fix formatting
Analyze - Apply statistical or qualitative methods to answer your questions
Visualize - Create tables, charts, and figures that show your findings
Document - Track every decision you make so others (and you, later!) understand what you did

title: âš™ï¸ Phase 4: Execution
text:
Phase 4 Content & Activities

Activity 1: Data Collection (Week 8)
Follow your approved data collection plan:

Collect data - Surveys, interviews, archival data, API scraping, etc.
Track whatâ€™s happening - Keep notes in 00_Inbox/ of collection date, sample size, issues
Store raw data - Save exactly as received in 03_Project/03_Data/raw/
Document sources - Who, when, where did this data come from?

Organize your data folder:
03_Project/03_Data/
â”œâ”€â”€ raw/              # Exactly as received (don't modify!)
â”œâ”€â”€ clean/            # After cleaning + transformation
â”œâ”€â”€ README.md         # Overview of datasets + versions

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
Welcome to the SIM Lab. If you are reading this, you likely identify as a â€œcreative.â€ You are a writer, a designer, a strategist, or a storyteller. You might feel that â€œresearchâ€ is the opposite of what you doâ€”a cold, clinical practice performed by people in lab coats who care more about numbers than people.
This chapter exists to dismantle that belief. Research is not the enemy of creativity; it is the engine of it. At its core, research is simply a specialized, rigorous form of the storytelling you are already passionate about. To be a great researcher, you must first understand the neuroscience of narrative.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
Welcome to the SIM Lab. If you are reading this, you likely identify as a â€œcreative.â€ You are a writer, a designer, a strategist, or a storyteller. You might feel that â€œresearchâ€ is the opposite of what you doâ€”a cold, clinical practice performed by people in lab coats who care more about numbers than people.
This chapter exists to dismantle that belief. Research is not the enemy of creativity; it is the engine of it. At its core, research is simply a specialized, rigorous form of the storytelling you are already passionate about. To be a great researcher, you must first understand the neuroscience of narrative.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
section: 1.1 Theoretical Foundation: The Brain as a Story Processor
text:
1.1 Theoretical Foundation: The Brain as a Story Processor
We begin not with statistics, but with neuroscience. In The Science of Storytelling, Will Storr argues that the human brain is not a logic processor, but a â€œstory processorâ€. This fundamental insight transforms how we approach both creative work and scientific inquiry.

The Control-Seeking Brain
The brainâ€™s primary evolutionary function is to control its environment to ensure survival. To do this, it builds internal modelsâ€”hallucinations, essentiallyâ€”of the world around us. We walk into a room and our brain instantly predicts:

The physics of the floor beneath our feet
The social dynamics of the people present
The safety of the space weâ€™re entering
The cultural norms we should follow

When these models work, we feel calm and confident. Our predictions match reality, and we navigate the world smoothly. But when they failâ€”when the floorboards crack unexpectedly, or a friend acts strangelyâ€”we feel anxiety. Our internal model has been disrupted.
This moment of disruption is what storytellers call the Inciting Incident. The brain demands an explanation to bridge the gap between what it expected and what happened. It generates a â€œstoryâ€ to regain control: â€œThe floor is old,â€ â€œMy friend is upset about something,â€ â€œI need to be careful here.â€
This is not metaphorâ€”this is cognitive architecture. The brain is literally constructing narrative explanations to maintain its sense of control over reality.


The Narrative Imperative
Consider this example: Youâ€™re scrolling through social media and notice that three different friends have posted about the same new app within 24 hours. Your brain immediately constructs explanatory narratives:

Story 1: â€œThis app must be going viral.â€
Story 2: â€œThereâ€™s probably an influencer campaign happening.â€
Story 3: â€œMaybe thereâ€™s a new feature that solves a common problem.â€

You havenâ€™t analyzed data. You havenâ€™t run statistics. Yet your brain has already generated three competing hypotheses to explain the pattern you observed. This is the storytelling mechanism at workâ€”and itâ€™s the foundation of scientific thinking.
The difference between casual observation and research is simply this: Research subjects these narrative explanations to systematic testing.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
1.2 Research as Plot
Scientific inquiry follows the exact same structure as a compelling novel. We can map the components of a standard research study directly onto the components of a narrative arc:

The Story Structure of Science

1. The Inciting Incident â†’ The Research Problem
The story begins with a gap in knowledge. You observe an anomaly in the media landscape that violates your expectations:

â€œWhy is everyone suddenly watching chess on Twitch?â€
â€œWhy did that Super Bowl ad go viral when others didnâ€™t?â€
â€œWhy are teen girls abandoning Instagram for BeReal?â€

This violation of your expectations drives the plot forward. In academic writing, we call this the research problem or research question. In screenwriting, itâ€™s the moment the protagonistâ€™s normal world shatters.
Example: In March 2020, we noticed people flooding onto Twitchâ€”not to watch esports professionals, but just to â€œhang outâ€ in low-stakes streams. This didnâ€™t match our model of Twitch as a gaming platform. That gap became our research question.


2. The Protagonist â†’ The Researcher
This is you. You are the detective entering the unknown world to find the truth. Like any protagonist, you bring:

Skills: Your training in theory, methods, and critical thinking
Tools: Your research instruments (surveys, scrapers, interviews)
Motivation: Curiosity, career goals, or a desire to solve a real-world problem
Constraints: Time, budget, ethical boundaries

Your journey through the research process will change you. By the end, youâ€™ll know something you didnâ€™t know beforeâ€”and that transformation is what makes you the protagonist.


3. The Antagonist â†’ The Data
In research, the antagonist is not a villain, but chaos. It is:

The overwhelming noise of unorganized information
The difficulty of accessing data
The complexity of human behavior
The statistical variation that obscures patterns
The ethical and logistical barriers to perfect knowledge

Your goal is to defeat this chaos by organizing it. You impose structure on the formless through:

Coding schemes that categorize messy text
Variables that quantify complex phenomena
Statistical tests that separate signal from noise
Visualizations that reveal hidden patterns

The antagonist resists. Your sample is biased. Your coding is inconsistent. Your results are inconclusive. The plot thickens.


4. The Rising Action â†’ Data Collection
Like any good story, research builds tension. You:

Design your study (plotting your path into the unknown)
Gain IRB approval (crossing the threshold)
Collect your data (venturing into the dark forest)
Encounter obstacles (participant dropout, API changes, messy data)

Each setback increases the stakes. Will you find the answer? Will the data support your hypothesis? The reader (or reviewer) leans forward.


5. The Climax â†’ The Analysis
This is the moment of truth. You run your statistical test or finalize your coding. The tension breaks, and the answer is revealed:

â€œp < .05â€ â€” The relationship is significant!
â€œKappa = .82â€ â€” The coding is reliable!
â€œr = .67â€ â€” The correlation is strong!

Or perhaps:

â€œp = .43â€ â€” No significant relationship found.
â€œThe data was too noisy to draw conclusions.â€

Even null findings tell a story. They tell us that the world is more complex than we thoughtâ€”that our initial model needs refinement.


6. The Resolution â†’ The Discussion
Like any storyâ€™s resolution, the Discussion section answers: â€œWhat does this mean?â€

How does this finding change our understanding?
What are the implications for practitioners?
What should we study next?
How do we update our model of the world?

The protagonist (you) has transformed. You entered with a question; you exit with an answer (or a more sophisticated question).



Example: Mapping a Real Study
Letâ€™s apply this to the Twitch study:








Story Element
Research Element
Our Example




Inciting Incident
Research Problem
People suddenly flocking to Twitch during quarantine


Protagonist
Researcher
SIM Lab team investigating streaming behavior


Antagonist
Data Chaos
Millions of chat messages, multiple languages, spam


Rising Action
Data Collection
Scraping 50,000+ chat logs from 200+ streams


Climax
Analysis
Statistical tests showing increased social/tension-release language


Resolution
Discussion
Twitch served as digital â€œthird placeâ€ during isolation

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
section: 1.3 The Sacred Flaw: The Null Hypothesis
text:
1.3 The Sacred Flaw: The Null Hypothesis
Perhaps the most powerful concept Storr offers is the â€œSacred Flaw.â€ In fiction, a protagonist often clings to an erroneous belief about the world that protects their identity:

â€œI donâ€™t need anyoneâ€ (Elsa in Frozen)
â€œMoney equals happinessâ€ (Charles Foster Kane in Citizen Kane)
â€œThe past defines meâ€ (Simba in The Lion King)

The plot forces them to confront this flaw. By the climax, they must abandon their false belief to achieve their goal.

The Null Hypothesis as Sacred Flaw
In science, we have a name for this Sacred Flaw: the Null Hypothesis (Hâ‚€).
The Null Hypothesis is the assumption that the world is boring and staticâ€”that there is no relationship between variables, no effect, and no change. It is the â€œflawedâ€ model we currently accept as true until proven otherwise.
Examples:







Sacred Flaw (Hâ‚€)
The Story (Hâ‚)




Violent video games have no effect on children
Actually, the data suggests they desensitize players to aggression


Social media usage is unrelated to anxiety
Actually, heavy use correlates with increased anxiety symptoms


Brand logos donâ€™t influence purchasing
Actually, exposure to luxury logos triggers status-seeking behavior


Streaming is just entertainment
Actually, it serves social integration functions during isolation



Scientific inquiry is the process of exposing the Sacred Flaws in our collective understanding of media. We assume the current model (Hâ‚€) is true until the data becomes so overwhelming that we are forced to rewrite the story.


The Burden of Proof
Just as a fictional protagonist must earn their transformation through struggle, we cannot simply declare the Sacred Flaw false. We must:

State the null clearly: â€œThere is no relationship between X and Yâ€
Collect rigorous evidence: Through valid, reliable methods
Test statistically: Is the pattern we see just random chance?
Reach a threshold: Typically p < .05 (less than 5% chance of randomness)
Only then reject Hâ‚€: And accept that the world is different than we thought

This is storytelling with stakes. Weâ€™re not just entertaining readersâ€”weâ€™re revising humanityâ€™s collective understanding of reality.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
1.4 Connecting Journalism to Data Science
If you can think like a journalist, you can act like a data scientist. Both professions share a single goal: to uncover the truth about the world. The difference lies only in the scale of the evidence.

The Journalistâ€™s Toolkit
A journalist investigates a story by:

Observing: Noticing patterns in the world (e.g., â€œEveryoneâ€™s talking about this new appâ€)
Interviewing: Gathering firsthand accounts (e.g., â€œI spoke to 10 users whoâ€¦â€)
Contextualizing: Providing historical and cultural background
Synthesizing: Weaving observations into a coherent narrative

The journalistâ€™s strength is depth. They can capture the texture of human experienceâ€”the fear in someoneâ€™s voice, the cultural nuance of a trend, the emotional weight of a moment.


The Data Scientistâ€™s Toolkit
A data scientist investigates the same story by:

Observing: Noticing patterns in data (e.g., â€œApp downloads increased 300%â€)
Measuring: Gathering systematic evidence (e.g., â€œWe tracked 10,000 users over 6 monthsâ€)
Modeling: Testing theoretical explanations statistically
Generalizing: Identifying patterns that apply beyond individual cases

The data scientistâ€™s strength is breadth. They can detect patterns invisible to individual observationâ€”the aggregate behavior of millions, the statistical correlation hidden in noise.


The Liaisonâ€™s Integration
You are learning to be both. You will:

Start with journalistic curiosity (Whatâ€™s happening? Why does it matter?)
Gather systematic evidence (Letâ€™s measure this at scale)
Analyze with statistical rigor (Is this pattern real or random?)
Communicate with narrative clarity (Hereâ€™s what this means for real people)

This is the power of the Communication Liaison: You speak both languages.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
section: 1.5 Case Study: Twitch in the Time of Quarantine
text:
1.5 Case Study: Twitch in the Time of Quarantine
To illustrate this evolution from journalist to data scientist, letâ€™s examine a study conducted at the SIM Lab: â€œTwitch in the Time of Quarantineâ€ (Leith & Gheen, 2022).

Phase 1: The Journalistâ€™s Observation
March 2020: As the COVID-19 lockdowns began, we noticed a massive cultural shift. Everyone we knew was suddenly logging onto Twitchâ€”not just for gaming, but just to â€œhang out.â€ Streams with low production value and no competitive gameplay were getting thousands of viewers.
A journalist might write a think-piece titled: â€œHow We Are Coping Online: The Rise of Parasocial Comfort in Digital Spaces.â€
This is a valid observation. Itâ€™s culturally insightful. But itâ€™s anecdotalâ€”based on personal experience and limited interviews. A skeptical editor might ask:

â€œHow do you know this is widespread?â€
â€œCould you just be noticing it because youâ€™re online more?â€
â€œWhatâ€™s the evidence beyond your friend group?â€



Phase 2: The Scientistâ€™s Inquiry
We took that observation and subjected it to the â€œScientific Plot.â€

The Inciting Incident (Research Problem)
Why are people flocking to a gaming site during a health crisisâ€”especially people who arenâ€™t gamers?


The Theory (Our Lens)
We applied Uses and Gratifications Theory (Katz, Blumler, & Gurevitch, 1974), which argues people use media to satisfy specific psychological needs:

Social Integrative needs: The need to belong, to feel connected
Tension Release needs: The need to escape, to relax

Our hypothesis: During quarantine, when in-person socializing became impossible, people turned to Twitch to satisfy these needs at scale.


The Investigation (Data Collection)
We scraped thousands of chat logs from Twitch streams spanning two time periods:

Pre-Pandemic: Januaryâ€“February 2020
During Pandemic: Marchâ€“May 2020

We collected: - Chat volume (messages per minute) - Emotional sentiment (positive, negative, neutral) - Social language (greetings, gratitude, community references) - Content focus (game-related vs.Â off-topic conversation)


The Analysis (The Climax)
Using computational text analysis and statistical testing, we found:

Chat volume increased 47% during the pandemic
Social integrative language increased 31% (e.g., â€œmiss you guys,â€ â€œfeels good to be hereâ€)
Tension-release expressions increased 28% (e.g., â€œneed this right now,â€ â€œescaping realityâ€)
Off-topic conversation increased 19% (people talking about quarantine life, not games)

Statistical tests confirmed these increases were significant (p < .001), meaning there was less than a 0.1% chance they occurred randomly.


The Resolution (Discussion)
We moved from â€œvibesâ€ (people seem lonely) to â€œvariablesâ€ (a statistically significant rise in social integrative messaging).
Our conclusion: During COVID-19 lockdowns, Twitch functioned as a digital third placeâ€”a public space where people gathered not to consume content, but to simply be together in a shared experience.



What Changed?







Journalistic Approach
Scientific Approach




â€œPeople seem to be using Twitch differentlyâ€
â€œChat volume increased 47% (p < .001)â€


â€œIt feels like a coping mechanismâ€
â€œTension-release language up 28%â€


â€œBased on my observationsâ€
â€œBased on analysis of 50,000+ messagesâ€


â€œThis matters to me and my communityâ€
â€œThis generalizes to millions of usersâ€



Both approaches are valuable. The journalist provides the soul (the human story). The scientist provides the spine (the empirical evidence).

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
section: 1.6 Anecdote vs.Â Data: The Creative Tension
text:
1.6 Anecdote vs.Â Data: The Creative Tension
The â€œJournalistâ€ in you collects anecdotes: specific, emotional stories about individuals.
Example: Interviewing one Twitch streamer about their anxiety during quarantine, hearing them describe crying during a stream when chat showed overwhelming support.
The â€œScientistâ€ in you collects data: the aggregation of thousands of anecdotes to prove a pattern.
Example: Counting how many streamersâ€™ chats contained supportive language, correlating it with viewership retention, and testing whether this pattern held across different stream categories.

Neither Is Sufficient Alone
A white paper with only data is dry:

â€œOur analysis of 50,000 chat messages revealed a 31% increase in social integrative language (M = 4.2, SD = 1.7) compared to baseline (M = 3.2, SD = 1.4), t(498) = 7.84, p < .001.â€

This is rigorous, but soulless. The readerâ€™s eyes glaze over.
A white paper with only anecdotes is unproven:

â€œI spoke to Sarah, a streamer who told me she felt more connected to her audience during quarantine. She said, â€˜It was like we were all going through this together.â€™ This shows how Twitch became a space for community during isolation.â€

This is compelling, but unscientific. The reader wonders: â€œBut is Sarahâ€™s experience typical? Or just one personâ€™s story?â€


The Liaisonâ€™s Synthesis
The Publisher (you, by Week 17) uses both:

â€œDuring the COVID-19 lockdowns, Twitch emerged as a digital refuge. Sarah, a variety streamer from Ohio, described the shift: â€˜It was like we were all going through this together.â€™ Our analysis of 50,000 chat messages confirms Sarahâ€™s intuition was widespreadâ€”social integrative language increased 31% during quarantine (p < .001), suggesting millions of users turned to Twitch not just for entertainment, but for human connection.â€

This synthesis: - Opens with context (the pandemic) - Introduces a human face (Sarah) - Uses her words (emotional resonance) - Validates with data (statistical evidence) - Explains significance (millions of users)
This is the power of combining journalism and data science. Youâ€™re not just reporting factsâ€”youâ€™re telling the truth in a way that moves people and withstands scrutiny.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
section: 1.7 The Research Mindset: From Consumer to Creator
text:
1.7 The Research Mindset: From Consumer to Creator
Most of your life, youâ€™ve been a consumer of research: reading studies, citing sources, trusting experts. In this course, you become a creator of research: generating knowledge, testing theories, adding to the scholarly conversation.
This shift requires three mental transformations:

1. From Certainty to Curiosity
Old Mindset: â€œThe answer is in the textbook. I just need to find it.â€
New Mindset: â€œThe answer doesnâ€™t exist yet. I need to create it.â€
Research is not about memorizing factsâ€”itâ€™s about generating new facts. You must become comfortable with uncertainty, ambiguity, and the possibility that your hypothesis is wrong.


2. From Description to Explanation
Old Mindset: â€œThis is what happened.â€ (Reporting)
New Mindset: â€œThis is why it happened.â€ (Analysis)
Description tells us what. Explanation tells us why. Theory provides the lens that transforms observation into insight.


3. From Opinion to Evidence
Old Mindset: â€œI think violent video games are harmful because they feel aggressive to me.â€
New Mindset: â€œI hypothesize violent video games increase aggression. Let me design an experiment to test this claim against competing explanations.â€
Opinions are starting points. Evidence is the destination. Research is the journey between them.

Pedagogical Rationale: Why GitHub?
Why not Blackboard or a Word doc?
In a constructivist learning environment, where you build determines who you become. GitHub is the industry standard for:

Software engineers
Data scientists
Open-source researchers
Digital humanists
Computational social scientists

By establishing your presence here, you are signalingâ€”to yourself and future employersâ€”that you are entering a technical domain.
The bio you write in your README.md is your first act of professional storytelling. You are no longer just a student; you are a researcher claiming your digital office.


What This Signals
When a future employer or graduate program Googles your name and finds your GitHub profile, they see:

Technical literacy: Youâ€™re comfortable in developer spaces
Public scholarship: Youâ€™re willing to work in the open
Professional identity: Youâ€™re building your career intentionally
Version control: You understand how modern knowledge work happens

This is not busywork. This is infrastructure for your future.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
Key Takeaways






TipRemember




The brain is a story processor â€” We use narratives to understand reality
Research follows narrative structure â€” Problem â†’ Investigation â†’ Discovery â†’ Meaning
The Null Hypothesis is the Sacred Flaw â€” Science exposes false beliefs about the world
Journalism + Data Science = Power â€” Combine depth and breadth for maximum impact
You are the protagonist â€” Research transforms both your knowledge and your identity

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
Further Reading

Storr, W. (2019). The Science of Storytelling. Abrams Press.
Katz, E., Blumler, J. G., & Gurevitch, M. (1974). Uses and gratifications research. Public Opinion Quarterly, 37(4), 509-523.
Leith, A. P., & Gheen, M. (2022). Parasocial relationships and streaming: Platform affordances and user motivations during COVID-19. Journal of Broadcasting & Electronic Media.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
Discussion Questions

Think of a moment when your â€œmodel of the worldâ€ was disrupted (an Inciting Incident). How did you construct a narrative to explain it?
Identify a media trend youâ€™ve noticed anecdotally. How would you transform that observation into a research question?
Whatâ€™s a â€œSacred Flawâ€ (Null Hypothesis) you hold about social media, gaming, or digital culture? How could you test whether itâ€™s actually true?

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
Next Chapter Preview
In Chapter 2: Entering the Field, weâ€™ll move from theory to practice. Youâ€™ll learn:

How to operationalize abstract concepts into measurable variables
The difference between conceptual and operational definitions
How to build a data dictionary for your own research project
Practical strategies for choosing the right research method

The story continuesâ€¦

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
R is the industry standard for statistical analysis, data visualization, and reproducible research in mass communications. RStudio is the professional interface that makes R accessible and powerful. Together, theyâ€™re essential tools for any Communication Liaison who works with data.
In this course, youâ€™ll use R to: - Clean and analyze data from surveys and content analysis - Create publication-ready visualizations and reports - Build reproducible workflows for your research - Collaborate on data analysis projects

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
R is the industry standard for statistical analysis, data visualization, and reproducible research in mass communications. RStudio is the professional interface that makes R accessible and powerful. Together, theyâ€™re essential tools for any Communication Liaison who works with data.
In this course, youâ€™ll use R to: - Clean and analyze data from surveys and content analysis - Create publication-ready visualizations and reports - Build reproducible workflows for your research - Collaborate on data analysis projects

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
What Youâ€™ll Install

R â€” The programming language (free, open-source)
RStudio â€” The professional development environment (free, open-source)

This is a two-step process: install R first, then RStudio.

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
Step 1: Install R

For Windows

Go to r-project.org
Click â€œDownload Râ€ in the left menu
Click the â€œDownload R for Windowsâ€ link
Click â€œbaseâ€
Click â€œDownload R X.X.X for Windowsâ€ (where X.X.X is the latest version number)
Run the installer (.exe file)

Click â€œNextâ€ through all screens
Accept the default installation location
Accept all default components

Click â€œFinishâ€

To verify installation: - Open PowerShell or Command Prompt - Type R --version - You should see Râ€™s version information


For macOS

Go to r-project.org
Click â€œDownload Râ€ in the left menu
Click â€œDownload R for macOSâ€
Download the appropriate .pkg file for your Mac:

Apple Silicon (M1/M2/M3 chips): Download the â€œARM64â€ version
Intel Macs: Download the â€œIntel 64â€ version
Not sure? Click the Apple icon (top left) â†’ â€œAbout This Macâ€ â†’ check under â€œProcessorâ€

Run the installer (.pkg file)

Click through all prompts
Accept the default installation location

Restart your Mac

To verify installation: - Open Terminal - Type R --version - You should see Râ€™s version information


For Linux (Ubuntu/Debian)
Open Terminal and run:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install r-base
To verify: Type R --version in Terminal.

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
Step 2: Install RStudio

For Windows, macOS, or Linux

Go to posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
Scroll down to â€œAll Installersâ€ or â€œDownload RStudio Desktopâ€
Select your operating system:

Windows: Download the .exe file
macOS: Download the .dmg file
Linux: Download the appropriate .deb or .rpm file

Run the installer

Windows: Click through all default options
Mac: Drag RStudio to Applications folder
Linux: Follow the package manager prompts

Open RStudio (you should see R is installed when you open it)

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
Step 3: Verify RStudio Works

Open RStudio (should be in your Applications/Programs menu)
You should see four panes:

Top left: Script editor (blank)
Bottom left: Console (shows > prompt)
Top right: Environment & History
Bottom right: Files, Plots, Packages, Help

In the Console (bottom left), type this command and press Enter:

print("Hello, Communication Liaison!")

You should see the output:

[1] "Hello, Communication Liaison!"
If you see this output, youâ€™re ready to go!

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
Step 4: Install Key Packages
RStudio comes with base R, but youâ€™ll need additional packages for data analysis. Open RStudio and copy these commands into the Console one at a time:

For Data Analysis & Visualization
install.packages("tidyverse")
This installs a collection of packages including: - ggplot2 â€” Create professional visualizations - dplyr â€” Clean and transform data - readr â€” Import data from CSV, Excel, etc. - tidyr â€” Reshape data
Wait for it to finish (youâ€™ll see a blank > prompt when done)


For Survey Analysis
install.packages("likert")
Used for analyzing Likert-scale survey responses.


For Reporting
install.packages("rmarkdown")
Creates professional PDF and HTML reports from your analysis.


Optional: Statistics Packages
For later phases, you might want these too:
install.packages("lm.beta")  # Standardized regression coefficients
install.packages("car")       # Post-hoc tests and diagnostics
install.packages("ggstatsplot")  # Statistical plots with test results

title: Install R & RStudio
section: Step 5: Create Your First R Project
text:
Step 5: Create Your First R Project
RStudio projects help you organize your work. Letâ€™s create one:

In RStudio, click File â†’ New Project
Select New Directory â†’ New Project
Name your project mc451-research or similar
Choose where to save it (suggest Documents)
Click Create Project

You should now see your project name in the top-right corner of RStudio.

title: Install R & RStudio
section: Step 6: Test Your Setup with Data
text:
Step 6: Test Your Setup with Data
Letâ€™s make sure everything works by loading a dataset:
In the Console, type:
# Load the tidyverse library
library(tidyverse)

# Load a built-in dataset
data(mtcars)

# View the first few rows
head(mtcars)
You should see a table with car data. If this works, your R setup is complete!

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
Understanding the RStudio Interface







Area
Purpose




Top Left (Script Editor)
Write R code here and save as .R files


Bottom Left (Console)
Results appear here; you can type commands directly


Top Right (Environment)
Shows all variables and data youâ€™ve loaded


Bottom Right (Files/Plots/Help)
Navigate files, view plots, access documentation

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
Basic RStudio Workflow

Create a new script: File â†’ New File â†’ R Script
Write code: Type your commands in the script
Run code: Select lines and press Ctrl+Enter (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Enter (Mac)
See results: Output appears in the Console or Plots pane
Save your work: Ctrl+S or File â†’ Save

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
Common First-Time Issues

â€œCommand not found: Râ€
Problem: Your computer doesnâ€™t recognize the R command.
Solution: - Try restarting your computer after installation - Check that R installed correctly (reinstall if needed) - On Mac/Linux, you may need to use /usr/bin/R instead


RStudio Opens But Doesnâ€™t Find R
Problem: RStudio says â€œR not foundâ€ when you open it.
Solution: 1. Make sure you installed R first (before RStudio) 2. In RStudio, go to Tools â†’ Global Options â†’ General 3. Under â€œR sessionsâ€, check the â€œR home directoryâ€ 4. If empty, browse to your R installation folder and select it 5. Click â€œOKâ€


â€œError: Could not find functionâ€
Problem: You get an error like could not find function "ggplot"
Solution: You need to load the package first. Run:
library(ggplot2)  # or whichever package you need


Installation Stuck or Takes Forever
Problem: install.packages() command seems frozen.
Solution: 1. Press Escape to stop it 2. Try installing from a different CRAN mirror:
install.packages("tidyverse", repos="https://cloud.r-project.org")


â€œPermission deniedâ€ Error (Mac/Linux)
Problem: Error when installing packages.
Solution: Try:
Sys.which("R")  # Check where R is installed
If youâ€™re still stuck, reach out during office hours.

title: Install R & RStudio
text:
Next Steps

âœ… Installed R
âœ… Installed RStudio
âœ… Verified it works
âœ… Installed key packages
Next: Learn R basics with your first assignment in Phase 2

R and RStudio have a learning curve, but the payoff is huge. If you run into issues:

Check the troubleshooting section above
Search stackoverflow.com for your error (others have likely encountered it)
Visit office hoursâ€”weâ€™ll debug together
Email with your specific error message

Youâ€™ve got this! ğŸ’ª

title: GitHub Deployment Instructions
text:
Go to https://github.com/SIM-Lab-SIUE
Click the â€œNewâ€ button (or go to https://github.com/organizations/SIM-Lab-SIUE/repositories/new)
Fill in the repository details:

Repository name: mc451-liaison-program (or your preferred name)
Description: Liaison Program course website with Obsidian vault for students
Visibility: Choose Public (so GitHub Pages works for free)
DO NOT initialize with README, .gitignore, or license (we already have these)

Click â€œCreate repositoryâ€




Once you create the repository, GitHub will show you commands. Use these:
git remote add origin https://github.com/SIM-Lab-SIUE/mc451-liaison-program.git
git push -u origin main
OR run this command in your terminal:
cd C:\mc451-sp26\quarto_website
git remote add origin https://github.com/SIM-Lab-SIUE/mc451-liaison-program.git
git push -u origin main



After pushing:

Go to your repository on GitHub
Click Settings â†’ Pages (in the left sidebar)
Under â€œBuild and deploymentâ€:

Source: Deploy from a branch
Branch: main
Folder: /_site

Click Save

GitHub will build your site. Wait 2-3 minutes, then your site will be live at:
https://sim-lab-siue.github.io/mc451-liaison-program/



Copy your GitHub Pages URL and post it in Blackboard:
ğŸ“š Course Website
Access all Liaison Program materials here:
https://sim-lab-siue.github.io/mc451-liaison-program/

You'll find:
âœ“ Getting started guide
âœ“ Liaison Obsidian Vault download
âœ“ All course modules and materials
âœ“ Weekly templates and resources

Start with the "Get Started" page!



Whenever you make changes:
cd C:\mc451-sp26\quarto_website
quarto render
git add .
git commit -m "Update course materials"
git push
GitHub Pages will automatically rebuild in 2-3 minutes.




If mc451-liaison-program is taken, try: - liaison-program-website - mc451-sp26 - communication-liaison-course - liaison-research-methods




Q: GitHub Pages shows 404 - Make sure you selected /_site folder (not root) - Wait 3-5 minutes for the first build - Check Settings â†’ Pages for build status
Q: Push failed - authentication error - You may need to set up a Personal Access Token - Go to GitHub Settings â†’ Developer settings â†’ Personal access tokens - Create token with repo scope - Use token as password when pushing
Q: Resource files (Liaison_Vault.zip) not showing - The .gitignore should NOT exclude resources/ - Check that resources/Liaison_Vault.zip was committed - Run: git ls-files resources/ to verify

Ready to go! Create the repository on GitHub, then run the push commands above. ğŸš€

title: Deployment Guide
text:
What You Have
âœ… Quarto Website - A fully functional, professional resource site

âœ… Built HTML - Ready to deploy (in the _site/ folder)

title: Deployment Guide
text:
Deployment Options

Option 1: GitHub Pages (Recommended - FREE)

Create a GitHub repository

Go to github.com and create a new public repo named quarto_website

Push your site
cd C:\mc451-sp26\quarto_website
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit: Liaison Program website"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/quarto_website.git
git push -u origin main
Enable GitHub Pages

Go to your repo Settings â†’ Pages
Set Source to â€œDeploy from a branchâ€
Set Branch to main and folder to _site
Your site will be live at: https://YOUR_USERNAME.github.io/quarto_website

Share the link in Blackboard

Copy the GitHub Pages URL
Add it to your Blackboard course as a web link or announcement




Option 2: Netlify (FREE, Easier Setup)

Go to netlify.com and sign up
Click â€œNew site from Gitâ€ and connect your GitHub repo
Set Build Command to: quarto render
Set Publish Directory to: _site
Deploy automatically on every push



Option 3: University Server/Portal
Contact your IT department about hosting the _site/ folder on your institutionâ€™s server.

title: About Dr.Â Leith
text:
Background
Iâ€™m an Associate Professor of Mass Communications at SIUE, where I direct the Social Interaction & Media Lab (SIM Lab). My research focuses on how people communicate, connect, and collaborate through digital platformsâ€”from video games and streaming to virtual reality and remote work environments.
Before joining SIUE, I completed my PhD in Information and Media at Michigan State University, where I studied gameplay livestreaming and how audiences build relationships with streamers. My masterâ€™s degree in Speech Communication from SIUE examined parasocial relationships on social media platforms like Facebook.

title: About Dr.Â Leith
text:
Research Interests
My current work explores:

Virtual Communication: How people interact, experience fatigue, and find authentic connection in virtual meetings and VR spaces
Gaming & Media: The psychology of gameplay, streaming, and how games shape communication and identity
Remote Work & Education: Supporting wellbeing and equity in virtual classrooms and distributed teams
Data & Communication: Using computational methods to understand media consumption and online behavior

title: About Dr.Â Leith
text:
Teaching Philosophy
I believe the best research methods courses empower students to ask good questions before worrying about technical answers. This course is structured around the idea that youâ€™re a Communication Liaisonâ€”someone who bridges data science and creative thinking.
Iâ€™m committed to: - Making research methods accessible (not just for math people) - Using real data and meaningful projects - Supporting diverse learning styles and backgrounds - Building a collaborative, judgment-free classroom

title: About Dr.Â Leith
text:
Current Projects
SIM Lab focuses on: - Improving equity and wellbeing in virtual classrooms - Understanding play and professionalism in remote environments
- Designing AI-enhanced tools for better virtual interaction - Building open-source resources for communication research
You can find more at: - Web: apleith.github.io - GitHub: github.com/apleith - ORCID: 0000-0003-1310-6763

title: Getting Started with GitHub
text:
As a Communication Liaison, youâ€™ll work with data and research projects that require collaboration and version control. GitHub is the industry standard for managing code, sharing research, and collaborating with teams. This guide walks you through creating your GitHub account and getting comfortable with the basics.
5-step fast path (10â€“15 minutes): 1. Create your GitHub account at github.com and verify email 2. Set a clear username + add a profile photo and short bio 3. Create a public repo initialized with a README (e.g., hello-world) 4. Install Git and clone the repo to your computer 5. Edit README, commit, and push back to GitHub

title: Getting Started with GitHub
text:
Step 1: Create Your GitHub Account

1.1 Go to GitHub
Open your web browser and navigate to github.com. Youâ€™ll see the GitHub homepage with a signup form.


1.2 Sign Up
Click the â€œSign upâ€ button (or the email field) and enter:

Email address: Use your SIUE email or personal email (you can change this later)
Password: Create a strong password (mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and symbols)
Username: Choose a professional username that youâ€™d be comfortable using in a job application

Tip: Avoid numbers or special characters if possible; keep it simple and memorable
Example: alex-leith or apleith works better than leith1993 or alex_code_master




1.3 Verify Your Email
GitHub will send you a verification email. Check your inbox, open the email from GitHub, and click the verification link. This confirms your account.


1.4 Complete Your Profile
After verification, GitHub will ask you setup questions:

Would you like to receive product updates and announcements via email? â†’ Your choice
How many people are in your team? â†’ Select â€œJust meâ€
What are you most interested in? â†’ Select options relevant to you (data, journalism, communication, etc.)

title: Getting Started with GitHub
text:
Step 3: Understand GitHubâ€™s Key Features

Repositories (Repos)
A repository is a folder that stores your project files, code, and documentation. Think of it as a project folder in the cloud that tracks all changes over time.


Creating a Test Repository
Letâ€™s create your first repository to get comfortable:

Click the â€œ+â€ icon (top right) â†’ New repository
Repository name: hello-world or my-first-repo
Description: â€œMy first GitHub repositoryâ€
Public or Private? â†’ Select Public (this is important for sharing your work)
â˜‘ï¸ Initialize with README (this creates a welcome file)
Click Create repository



The README File
Every repository should have a README.md file. This is like a cover page that explains: - What the project is about - How to use it - Who created it
When you visit a repository on GitHub, the README appears automatically below the file list.

title: Getting Started with GitHub
section: Step 4: Clone a Repository (Get It on Your Computer)
text:
Step 4: Clone a Repository (Get It on Your Computer)

4.1 Install Git
To work with repositories on your computer, you need Git (the tool GitHub uses).
Windows: 1. Download Git from git-scm.com 2. Run the installer and follow default options 3. Restart your computer
Mac: 1. Download Git from git-scm.com or use Homebrew 2. Open Terminal and run: brew install git
Linux: Open Terminal and run:
sudo apt-get install git


4.2 Clone Your First Repository

Go to your hello-world repository on GitHub
Click the green â€œCodeâ€ button
Copy the HTTPS URL (should look like https://github.com/yourusername/hello-world.git)
Open Terminal (Mac/Linux) or PowerShell (Windows)
Navigate to where you want to store your repository:
cd Documents
Clone the repository:
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/hello-world.git
Enter the repository folder:
cd hello-world

Congratulations! You now have a copy of your repository on your computer.

title: Getting Started with GitHub
text:
Step 5: Make Your First Commit

5.1 Edit Your README

Open the folder hello-world on your computer
Find the file README.md and open it in a text editor (Notepad, VS Code, etc.)
Add some content:

# Hello World

This is my first GitHub repository.

## About Me
- I'm a Communication Liaison
- I'm learning research methods
- I'm excited to collaborate

## Goals
- Master data analysis
- Tell stories with data
- Connect technical and creative teams

Save the file



5.2 Push Changes to GitHub
Back in Terminal/PowerShell, run these commands:
# Stage your changes (tell Git which files to save)
git add README.md

# Commit your changes (save them locally with a message)
git commit -m "Update README with introduction"

# Push changes to GitHub (send them to the website)
git push
Go back to GitHub.com, refresh your hello-world repository page, and youâ€™ll see your updated README!

title: Getting Started with GitHub
text:
Step 6: GitHub Vocabulary & Key Concepts







Term
Meaning




Repository (Repo)
A folder that stores your project and its history


Commit
A saved version of your work with a message describing what changed


Push
Send your local changes to GitHub


Pull
Download changes from GitHub to your computer


Branch
A separate version of your project (useful for testing new ideas)


Issue
A task, bug, or discussion for a project


Pull Request (PR)
A proposal to add changes from one branch to another


Fork
Create your own copy of someone elseâ€™s repository

title: Getting Started with GitHub
text:
Step 7: Best Practices

1. Use Clear Commit Messages
Bad: â€œUpdate stuffâ€ or â€œFixâ€
Good: â€œAdd data analysis section to READMEâ€ or â€œFix typo in methods sectionâ€


2. Commit Often
Make commits when you complete a logical task, not just once per day.


3. Keep Your README Updated
Your README is the first impression. Keep it current and clear.


4. Make It Public
For this course, make your repository public so I can see your work. You can always make it private later for sensitive projects.


5. Use Meaningful Repository Names
Bad: project or stuff
Good: mc451-research-analysis or data-storytelling-project

title: Getting Started with GitHub
text:
Step 8: Troubleshooting

â€œPermission deniedâ€ Error
If you see Permission denied (publickey), you need to set up SSH authentication. For now, use HTTPS (which youâ€™re already doing). Later, GitHub has tutorials to set up SSH if needed.


Changes Not Appearing on GitHub
Make sure you: 1. âœ… Used git add to stage files 2. âœ… Used git commit -m "message" to commit 3. âœ… Used git push to push to GitHub
All three steps are necessary!


How to Undo a Commit
If you made a mistake, run:
git log  # See your commit history
git revert HEAD  # Undo the last commit

title: Getting Started with GitHub
text:

As a student, GitHub offers free premium features and tools through their Student Developer Pack.

9.1 Apply for Student Benefits

Go to education.github.com
Click â€œSign up for Student Developer Packâ€ (or â€œGet benefitsâ€)
Sign in with your GitHub account
Enter your school: Southern Illinois University Edwardsville
Upload proof of enrollment:

Student ID card
Class schedule screenshot
Acceptance letter or tuition bill

Verify your SIUE email address (check your inbox for verification)
Submit your application

GitHub typically approves student applications within a few days.


9.2 What You Get (Free!)
Once approved, youâ€™ll have access to: - GitHub Copilot - AI-powered code assistant - Microsoft Azure - Cloud computing credits - JetBrains IDE Suite - Professional development tools - Datadog - Application monitoring - Plus 50+ other tools and services
This is especially useful for data analysis, coding projects, and learning advanced tools!

title: Install VS Code (Recommended)
text:
VS Code (Visual Studio Code) is a professional, lightweight code editor used by developers worldwide. While RStudio handles R code well, VS Code is excellent for:

Writing Python scripts for data analysis and automation
Managing Git repositories and GitHub

title: Weekly Journal Entry Guide
text:
Each week, youâ€™ll reflect on course material using one of three approaches. Pick the one that connects most to what youâ€™re thinking about this week.






Definition: Link this weekâ€™s material to something biggerâ€”your project, a previous concept, real-world examples, or your own experience.

Definition: Document a challenge you faced and how you worked through itâ€”technical, conceptual, or practical.

Definition: Ask a critical question about the material. Challenge an assumption, identify a gap, or explore an implication.

Length: 250-300 words

section: Your Role as a Communication Liaison
text:
Your Role as a Communication Liaison
A Communication Liaison bridges the gap between:

Data Scientists who understand the numbers
Creative Teams who understand the audience
Project Stakeholders who understand the goals

Your job is to translate, facilitate, and documentâ€”turning complex insights into clear action.

The Liaison Mindset

Translate: Turn jargon into clarity
Facilitate: Help people understand each other
Document: Create records for future reference
Guide: Lead projects toward success

title: ğŸ“– Phase 3: The Dictionary
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of Phase 3, you will:


âœ… Define variables, constructs, and measurement rules
âœ… Build a comprehensive data dictionary/codebook
âœ… Test definitions with pilot data
âœ… Document coding decisions and edge cases
âœ… Assess inter-coder reliability
âœ… Iterate on definitions based on pilot testing

title: ğŸ“– Phase 3: The Dictionary
text:
What Youâ€™ll Do
A data dictionary is like a translation guide for your data. It tells anyone (including future you!) exactly what each variable means:

Variable names - How is this stored in your data?
Definitions - What does this variable measure?
Types - Is it text, number, date, category?
Allowed values - What answers are valid?
Examples - Real samples of how to code things
Special rules - Edge cases and how to handle them

title: ğŸ“– Phase 3: The Dictionary
text:
Phase 3 Content & Activities

Activity 1: Start Your Data Dictionary (Week 5)

Copy the Template - Get the Data Dictionary Template from your vault
List Your Variables - From your research questions, what will you measure?
Define Each One - Write clear definitions for every variable
Specify Types - Is each variable numeric, text, categorical, etc.?

Example:










Variable
Definition
Type
Values
Example




age_group
Age category of respondent
Categorical
18-25, 26-35, 36-45, 45+
â€œ26-35â€


engagement_score
1-10 scale of user interaction frequency
Numeric
1-10 (whole numbers)
7


content_type
Primary content category shared
Text
Any string â‰¤100 chars
â€œnews_articleâ€



Submit: First draft in 03_Project/02_Codebook/Data_Dictionary_v1.md


Activity 2: Pilot Code Your Data (Week 6)
Test your definitions on a small sample:

Select 10-20 items - Sample from your actual data
Code them - Use your definitions to code each item
Track problems - What was ambiguous or unclear?
Document decisions - How did you resolve edge cases?

Create: 03_Project/02_Codebook/Pilot_Decisions_Log.md
Example entry:
VARIABLE: content_type
PROBLEM: Item #5 is a news article shared as a screenshot
DECISION: Code as "news_article" (focus on content, not format)
APPLIED: Items #5, #12, #18


Activity 3: Get Feedback (Week 7)
Optional: Inter-Coder Reliability Check
If possible, have a peer code the same 10-20 items independently:

Compare your coding - How often did you agree?
Discuss disagreements - Why did you code differently?
Update your definitions - Make them clearer if needed

Measure: Calculate % agreement or Cohenâ€™s Kappa (your instructor will guide this)


Activity 4: Finalize & Iterate (Week 7)
Based on your pilot testing:

Clarify definitions - Rewrite anything that was confusing
Add more examples - Include edge cases you found
Update allowed values - Add any new categories you discovered
Document assumptions - What did you decide to do and why?

Submit: 03_Project/02_Codebook/Data_Dictionary_v2_Final.md + Pilot Summary

title: ğŸ“– Phase 3: The Dictionary
text:
Key Concepts

Variable Types
Numeric - Numbers you can do math with (age, score, count)
Categorical - Limited set of categories (gender, region, type)
Text/String - Free-form text (name, comment, description)
Date - Time-based (2024-01-15)
Boolean - True/False or Yes/No


Measurement Scales
Nominal - Categories with no order (blue, red, green)
Ordinal - Ranked categories (low, medium, high)
Interval - Numbers with equal spacing (temperature inÂ°C)
Ratio - Numbers with true zero (height, weight, age)

A: Start with what you know. You can add more in Phase 4.

title: ğŸ¯ Phase 5: Delivery
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of Phase 5, you will:


âœ… Transform data findings into compelling narratives
âœ… Create visualizations tailored for different audiences
âœ… Write executive summaries and briefs
âœ… Present findings with confidence and clarity
âœ… Translate statistics into actionable insights
