title: ğŸ¯ Phase 5: Delivery
text:
What Youâ€™ll Do
This is your moment to tell the story your data reveals:
Narrative Development - Translate numbers into meaning: â€œWhat did we learn?â€
Visual Communication - Design slides/infographics that guide your audience through the story
Executive Briefing - One-page summary for decision makers
Presentation - Present findings in a clear, engaging way
Reflection - Capture lessons learned for next time

title: ğŸ¯ Phase 5: Delivery
text:
Phase 5 Content & Activities

Activity 1: Craft Your Story (Week 11)
Before making slides, nail your narrative:

Identify your key insights - Which 2-3 findings matter most?
Create an outline - How do you guide your audience through the data?
Add â€œSo what?â€ - For each finding, explain why it matters

Outline Template:
# Research Story Outline

## Hook (30 seconds)
[What question were we answering? Why does it matter?]

## Context (1-2 minutes)
[Brief background: who cares, what was the challenge?]

## The Findings (3-4 minutes)
### Finding 1: [Headline]
- Data point 1
- Data point 2
- **So what?** [Why does this matter? What should we do?]

### Finding 2: [Headline]
- Data point 1
- Data point 2
- **So what?** [Implications]

### Finding 3: [Headline]
- Data point 1
- Data point 2
- **So what?** [Action items]

## Limitations (1 minute)
[What are we uncertain about?]

## Next Steps (1-2 minutes)
[What should happen next?]
Create: 03_Project/04_Drafts/Story_Outline.md


Activity 2: Create a Slide Deck or Brief (Week 12)
Option A: Slide Deck (for live presentation) - Title slide with question - 1 context slide - 2-3 finding slides with visualizations - 1 limitations slide - 1 next steps/call-to-action slide - Total: 7-8 slides (aim for 1-2 minutes per slide)
Option B: One-Page Brief (for email/sharing) - Header with research question - 3-4 key findings with visual - Brief interpretation - Limitations (small print) - Contact + next steps
Design Tips: - âœ… One major idea per slide - âœ… Large, readable fonts (18pt minimum) - âœ… Colors that support understanding (not decoration) - âœ… Real data visuals (your actual charts/tables) - âœ… Simple, clean layouts - âŒ Avoid: dense text, clip art, too many colors
Tools: - Google Slides (free, easy sharing) - PowerPoint (familiar, flexible) - Keynote (Apple, polished) - Canva (beautiful templates) - Quarto (reproducible, code-based)
Create: 03_Project/04_Drafts/Presentation_Deck.pdf or Brief.pdf


Activity 3: Translate for Your Audience (Week 12)
Different audiences, different messages:
For Executives: - Bottom line: Whatâ€™s the recommendation? - Impact: What does this mean for our goals? - Minimize jargon; focus on action
For Data Scientists: - Methodology: How did you approach this? - Limitations: What arenâ€™t we capturing? - Code & details available if needed
For General Audience: - Story: What happened and why does it matter? - Visuals: Show donâ€™t tell - Plain language: Avoid stats jargon
Create: Brief version (1-2 sentences) of each finding for different audiences in your outline.


Activity 4: Presentation & Reflection (Week 13)
Presentation Options: - In-class presentation (5-10 minutes) - Recorded video (3-5 minutes) - Written report with visuals - Poster presentation (if poster session)
Before presenting: 1. Rehearse with a peer - Get feedback 2. Time yourself - Stay within limits 3. Check visuals - Do all graphs display correctly? 4. Practice Q&A - What might people ask?
After presenting: 1. Capture feedback - What questions did people ask? 2. Note surprises - What did people react to most? 3. Reflect in journal - What would you do differently next time?

Sample Presentation Structure (7-minute version)
Slide 1: Title (30 sec) - Research question - Your name - Date
Slide 2: Why This Matters (1 min) - Context - Why weâ€™re investigating this
Slides 3-4: The Findings (2.5 min) - Finding 1 + visual - Finding 2 + visual - Finding 3 + visual (if time)

Total: ~7 minutes + Q&A

title: Installing R & RStudio
text:
R and RStudio are essential tools for statistical analysis and data science in this course. This guide covers installation on all major operating systems.



R: The core statistical programming language and environment
RStudio: An IDE (Integrated Development Environment) that makes R much easier to use









Go to CRAN (Comprehensive R Archive Network)
Click â€œDownload R for Windowsâ€
Click â€œbaseâ€ (first option)
Click the download link for the latest version (typically named something like R-4.x.x-win.exe)
Run the installer

Accept default settings (you can leave everything as-is)
Click through the installation wizard
Installation typically takes 2-5 minutes






Go to Posit RStudio Downloads
Click â€œDownload RStudio Desktopâ€ for Windows
Run the installer

Accept default settings
The installer will detect your R installation automatically
Complete the installation






Open RStudio (search for it in Windows Start menu)
In the Console pane (usually bottom-left), you should see something like:
R version 4.x.x (20XX-XX-XX) -- "..."
Type: print("Hello, R!") and press Enter
If you see [1] "Hello, R!", youâ€™re ready to go!








Option A: Using the installer (Recommended for beginners)

Go to CRAN macOS
Click â€œDownload R for macOSâ€
Select the appropriate version:

For Apple Silicon (M1/M2/M3 chips): Download R-x.x.x-arm64.pkg
For Intel Macs: Download R-x.x.x-x86_64.pkg
(Unsure? Check Apple menu â†’ About This Mac â†’ Chip)

Run the .pkg installer and follow the prompts
Installation takes 2-5 minutes

Option B: Using Homebrew (if you use Homebrew)
brew install r




Go to Posit RStudio Downloads
Click â€œDownload RStudio Desktopâ€ for macOS
Select the appropriate version for your Mac (Apple Silicon or Intel)
Open the downloaded .dmg file
Drag RStudio to the Applications folder
Launch RStudio from Applications





Open RStudio (find in Applications folder or Spotlight search)
In the Console, type: print("Hello, R!") and press Enter
Confirm you see: [1] "Hello, R!"








# Update package lists
sudo apt update

# Install R
sudo apt install -y r-base r-base-dev




Go to Posit RStudio Downloads
Select â€œRStudio Desktopâ€ â†’ Choose Linux version (Ubuntu 20/22 or Debian)
Download the .deb file
Install it:
sudo dpkg -i rstudio-[version].deb

Or install from terminal directly:
sudo apt install -y rstudio




Launch RStudio from applications menu or terminal:
rstudio &
Test in Console: print("Hello, R!")
Confirm output: [1] "Hello, R!"







Once R and RStudio are installed, you need to set up your R environment for the course:


In RStudio Console, run:
setwd("~/Documents")  # Or your preferred workspace folder



Weâ€™ll use these packages throughout the course. Install them with:
# Core data science packages
install.packages(c(
  "tidyverse",      # Data wrangling and visualization
  "rmarkdown",      # Create documents with R code
  "quarto",         # Publishing system
  "shiny",          # Interactive web apps
  "ggplot2"         # Advanced visualization
))
This may take 5-15 minutes (packages are downloading and installing).



Test that the main packages work:
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
print("All packages loaded successfully!")
If no errors appear, youâ€™re all set!








Windows: Try reinstalling R with administrator privileges
Mac: Restart your computer and try again
Linux: Run sudo apt install -y r-base to ensure all dependencies are installed





RStudio should auto-detect R, but if not:

Tools â†’ Global Options â†’ General
Look for â€œR versionâ€ section
If blank, manually browse to your R installation






Make sure you have internet connection
Try: install.packages("package_name", repos="http://cran.r-project.org")
Some packages require additional system libraries (ask in course chat!)





Try: install.packages("package", type="source")









Action
Command




See R version
R.version.string


List installed packages
library()


Load a package
library(package_name)


Install a package
install.packages("package_name")


Get help
help(function_name) or ?function_name


Exit R
q()








Official R Documentation: https://www.r-project.org/
RStudio Cheat Sheets: https://posit.co/resources/cheatsheets/
R for Data Science (Book): https://r4ds.hadley.nz/
Course Support: Check the course discussion board for questions

Youâ€™re ready to start the course! See you in Module 1.

title: Getting Started
text:
This page will guide you through your initial setup. Complete these steps before Phase 1.
Time needed: ~20â€“25 minutes total. Follow the steps in order.

title: Getting Started
text:
This page will guide you through your initial setup. Complete these steps before Phase 1.
Time needed: ~20â€“25 minutes total. Follow the steps in order.

title: Getting Started
text:
Step 1: Download Your Workspace (5 minutes)
Visit the Resources page and download the Liaison_Vault.zip file.
Extract it to a location like: - Mac/Linux: ~/Documents/Liaison_Vault - Windows: C:\Users\YourName\Documents\Liaison_Vault

title: Getting Started
text:
Step 2: Install Obsidian (5 minutes)

Go to obsidian.md and download Obsidian
Install it on your computer
Open Obsidian and select â€œOpen folder as vaultâ€
Navigate to your Liaison_Vault folder and open it

First time in Obsidian? - Click the folder icon on the left sidebar to see your vault structure - Open 00_START_HERE.md to read your orientation guide

title: Getting Started
text:
Step 3: Configure Obsidian Settings (3 minutes)
Once your vault is open in Obsidian:

Go to Settings (gear icon, bottom left)
Click Files & Links in the sidebar
Under â€œDefault location for new attachmentsâ€, select 04_Resources
This ensures all images, PDFs, and media files go to the right place

title: Getting Started
text:
Step 4: Explore Your Vault Structure
Your vault contains:








Folder
Purpose
Action




00_Inbox
Quick notes & ideas
Capture thoughts here first


01_Journal
Weekly reflections
Use the template to reflect each week


02_Literature
Reading notes
Store all your research notes here


03_Project
Active research work
Organize by prospectus, codebook, data, drafts


04_Resources
Media & attachments
Images, PDFs, external files


99_Templates
Reusable templates
Copy these to start assignments

title: Getting Started
section: Step 5: Review the Weekly Journal Template (5 minutes)
text:
Step 5: Review the Weekly Journal Template (5 minutes)
Open 99_Templates â†’ Weekly_Journal_Template.md (or preview it here)
This template guides you to reflect using one of three thinking paths: - The Connector: How does this apply to my project? - The Troubleshooter: What broke and how did I fix it? - The Critic: Does this hold true in my experience?
Want a head start on later phases? Preview the Data Dictionary Template here so you know how variables will be documented.

title: Getting Started
text:
Step 6: Youâ€™re Ready!
Once you complete these steps, move to Phase 1: Orientation in the sidebar to begin.

title: Getting Started
text:
Troubleshooting
Q: I extracted the ZIP file but Obsidian wonâ€™t open it as a vault - Make sure youâ€™re opening the folder that contains the .obsidian hidden folder - Try right-clicking the folder and checking â€œShow hidden filesâ€ if needed
Q: Where do I put my weekly journal entries? - Create a new file in 01_Journal named something like Week_01_MyName.md - Copy the template from 99_Templates/Weekly_Journal_Template.md and fill it out
Q: Can I share my vault with classmates? - Yes! You can email them the ZIP file, or sync it via Git/GitHub for collaborative projects

Questions? Reach out via your course management system or check your course syllabus for contact information.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course Overview
This course equips you with research methodologies, tools, and frameworks to excel as a Communication Liaisonâ€”bridging data scientists and creative teams. Over 17 weeks across five phases, youâ€™ll develop skills to navigate data-driven projects while maintaining clear communication with all stakeholders.

text:
At a Glance

Grading Breakdown (summary)

Participation and weekly journal reflections
Phase deliverables (Discovery, Dictionary, Execution)
Final presentation/brief in Phase 5



Weekly Rhythm

Mon/Wed class: activities, demos, peer feedback
Weekly journal: use 01_Journal with the Weekly Journal Template
Check-ins: office hours or email; bring blockers early



Key Policies

Come prepared with vault set up by Week 2
Late work: see full PDF for details and extensions
Academic integrity: cite data sources and collaborators

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Quick Reference

Course Structure: Five Phases

Phase 1: Orientation â€” Understand your role and set up your workspace
Phase 2: Discovery â€” Learn research methodologies and ask the right questions
Phase 3: The Dictionary â€” Master codebook creation and variable definition
Phase 4: Execution â€” Apply what youâ€™ve learned to real projects
Phase 5: Delivery â€” Present findings and communicate impact



Key Resources

Liaison Obsidian Vault â€” Download on the Resources page
Weekly Journal Template â€” Included in vault; guidance on the Resources page
Data Dictionary Template â€” Included in vault for Week 8â€“10 projects



Getting Help

Office hours: Stop by anytime during posted hours or schedule an appointment
Email: Send questions to aleith@siue.edu
Course site: Check the sidebar for Phase-specific materials and guidance
